subject: US MARKET WRAP 8 March 2019: Doubts grow over Trump/Xi meeting; NFP headline posts big miss
content:
* SNAP SHOT: Equities down, dollar down, Treasuries up, crude .

* REAR VIEW: Payrolls miss; Trump/Xi meeting potentially pushed back; EU’s Barnier proposes a non-starter,

* NEXT WEEK: German trade; US retail sales; Business Inventories; US President Trump release prelim overview of budget; UK PM May to meet with EC President Juncker; US 3yr note auction; Earnings from Deutsche Post and Uniper;

HEADS-UP: On Sunday, US moves onto summer time, and clocks will move forward by one hour. with UK time not changing for another two weeks. This means that between Sunday March 10th and Sunday March 31st, the gap between London and NY will be 4 hrs and London/Chicago will be 5 hrs.

* NON-FARM PAYROLLS: US nonfarm payrolls missed expectations by some margin, printing 20k vs a consensus 180k. "The 180K consensus for payrolls appeared completely to ignore the huge overshoot to trend in January, which screamed risk of a hefty downside correction," Pantheon said, "in the event the downshift was bigger than we expected but the 186K average increase in payrolls in the past three months is entirely respectable." The consultancy notes that while indicators of labour demand have softened slightly, they were not weak enough to suggest that the February data is signalling the beginning of a new trend, and Pantheon sees a return towards trend rates next month. On a brighter note, AHE rose to 3.4% YY; Pantheon said the jump was a correction after the January number was depressed by the long-standing calendar distortion, which Pantheon says depresses reported AHE in months when the 15th - payday for people paid semi-monthly - falls after the survey week. "Firms are meant to report wages on an accruals basis but some appear to report only cash outlays, so AHE looks soft in these months and then rebounds, adding though that "still, the YY rate rose to a new cycle high of 3.4%, and we expect further gains ahead as employees increasingly flex their muscles in the labour market," adding that "the late cycle scarcity premium finally is emerging." Meanwhile, the jobless rate fell to 3.8% from 4.0%, perhaps due to household employment rebounding, reversing the January fall, while the size of the labour force fell slightly. "The bottom line," Pantheon concludes, "is that this report has something for hawks (wages) and doves (payrolls); it won't move the needle at the Fed."

* TRADE: Once again the enforcement issues of the trade deal were at the forefront of traders’ minds, though ultimately there is still little clarity on how any trade would be enforced. Following the NYT report that Chinese officials were pessimistic on a trade deal being made quickly; Politico cited a senior White House official playing down the article, however, suggesting that it has always been true that the non-retaliation pledge would be a tough for Beijing to accept. US NEC Director Kudlow commented too today, and said negotiations between the two sides were ongoing. Kudlow added to the uncertainty after suggesting that a meeting between Trump and Xi could happen at either the end of this month or early April; previous guidance suggested a meeting at Mar-a-Lago on the 27th March, so any delay to that timeline would highlight the challenging nature of the negotiations. In later trade, it was reported that Chinese reportedly have reomved the trip to Mar-a-Lago from China President Xi's calendar, Fox reported.

* BREXIT: As crunch time approaches for PM May and her Brexit plan, this week once again was another ‘stalemate’ with both the UK and EU still seemingly far apart in their demands which culminated in AG Cox and Brexit Secretary Barclay scrapping their visit to Brussels on Friday. Today saw EU Chief Brexit negotiator Barnier echo this sentiment, saying that no progress had been made in Brexit talks, however he did propose some legally binding interpretations for the withdrawal agreement. Barnier proposed that the EU commits to give the UK the option to exit the single customs territory unilaterally, but added that the other elements of the backstop must be maintained to avoid a hard border. Although UK government sources soon rejected this, with DUP leader Dodds describing Barnier’s proposals as a “non-starter”. Dodds went on to say that the EU’s offer was neither realistic, nor sensible, saying it disrespects the constitutional and economic integrity of the UK, and was an attempt to get ahead in a possible blame game. And this is the key here; ahead of next week’s votes in the UK, sides are already jockeying to pass blame onto the other side, something which was a motivating factor for Barnier to tweet his proposals.

* WTI (J9) SETTLES USD 0.59 LOWER AT USD 56.07/BBL, BRENT (K9) SETTLES USD 0.56 LOWER AT USD 65.74/BBL. Crude prices ended the week on a down note, after reaching weekly highs on Thursday. The complex began its selloff overnight – taking cues from the strong drop in Chinese equities – and continued its downward trajectory on the back of a NFP headline miss. The market has become increasingly alert and sensitive to the demand side of the equation, in which the narrative of slowing global growth becomes more and more evident. In Friday’s news flow, Saudi production stood at 10.316mln BPD in February, according to industry sources, which is a slightly higher figure than the Platts survey on Thursday which reported output at 10.15mln BPD from the key OPEC producer. Baker Hughes (March 8): oil rigs -9 at 834, nat gas rigs -2 at 193, total rigs -11 at 1027.

* SPX -0.2% at 2743, NDX -0.2% at 7016, DJI -0.1% at 25448. SECTORS: Energy -1.9%, Materials +0.2%, Industrials -0.3%, Cons Discretionary -0.7%, Cons Staples +0.1%, Healthcare -0.2%, Financials 0.0%, Tech 0.0%, Telecoms -0.1%, Utilities +0.3%.

* STOCKS SPECIFICS: Costco (COST) surged on Friday on the release of its earnings report where it beat on EPS estimates, and reported an easing of margin pressures. The energy complex nosedived, primarily due to the dip in crude prices; worth noting Norway’s sovereign wealth fund also announced its plans to cut its stake in oil companies, which included Exxon Mobil (XOM), Chevron (CVX) and ConocoPhillips (COP). Gilead Sciences (GILD) caught a bid on promising study results from HIV treatments. National Beverage (FIZZ) tanked after a disappointing earnings report. Netflix (NFLX) suffered from a downgrade at Buckingham, who cite investor angst over Disney’s (DIS) approaching streaming service. Horizon Pharma (HZNP) benefitted from an upgrade at Morgan Stanley, who say the co.’s entry into rare diseases isn’t appreciated enough.

* US T-NOTE FUTURES (M9) SETTLED 3+ TICKS HIGHER AT 122-24+. As the Tsy complex wraps up for the week, the T Note future has added only 3+ ticks at settlement, despite the NFP headline mis which took the June contract to highs of 122-31, and then snap to lows around 122-19, before continuing its sideways grind at relatively unchanged levels. There was buying after the Europeans had left for the week, which took the contract form around 122-21 to around 122-26. At settlement, major curve spreads were slightly narrower, but under 1bps.

* EUR: A partial reprieve for the single currency, at least in USD and GBP terms, as the former is undermined by a significantly weaker than expected headline NFP print and the latter by no Brexit backstop breakthrough following the latest round of talks between UK and EU officials. However, Eur/Usd remains rooted to the lows of the week within a circa 1.1395-1.1185 range after stubborn resolve around the 1.1300 handle was finally broken by the ECB via the launch of TLTRO mark 3 and revised rate guidance to signal unchanged benchmarks through year end from at least after Summer 2019 previously. President Draghi delivered the rationale at the post-meeting press conference and during the Q&A, but the bottom line is that the downturn in economic activity is now deemed to be sustained and widespread, and this was reflected in the updated March Staff forecasts via especially large downgrades to 2019 growth and inflation. Sources then compounded the dovish developments with suggestions that some GC members believe the GDP projection for this year may still be too optimistic, while even the more hawkish faction are said to have raised no real objections to the policy actions as waiting longer would not make sense.

* AUD/NZD: The Aussie suffered a similar, albeit not as painful in absolute terms fate as the Euro amidst more dismal data and the RBA underlining its neutral stance, with nuances towards the balance of probability shifting from 50-50 between tightening and easing as the next move. Governor Lowe effectively removed a hike from the 2019 agenda and after GDP data showing the nation in a per capita recession, a herd of banks joined Westpac’s aggressive at the time call for 2 cuts this year, and one predicting back-to-back reductions of 25 bp. Aud/Usd got to within a whisker of 0.7000 vs 0.7100+ at one stage ahead of a 1.5 bn option expiry at the strike in the up to the NY cut, but pared losses on the aforementioned post-US jobs data Greenback downturn. Conversely, the Kiwi is actually close to ending a turbulent week back up around 0.6800 and not far from where it started or the peak (0.6830), partly as the Usd pulled back, but mainly due to favourable cross-winds as Aud/Nzd tested the water below 1.03500.

* JPY/CHF: A solid showing by the renowned safe-haven currencies on Friday, but over the week quite a different story as the Jpy has sharply outperformed on a broad deterioration in risk sentiment due to heightened global growth jitters. Indeed, Usd/Jpy retreated from a series of tops around 112.00 and just above the big figure through key chart support at the 200 DMA (111.39) and under 111.00, while Yen crosses have also recoiled markedly. Conversely, Usd/Chf has rebounded back above parity all the way to 1.0100+ before waning and even though the Franc has netted gains vs the Euro.

* GBP: Another week of Brexit watching for the Pound, as noted above, with Cable initially boosted by high/rising hopes of a breakthrough on the Irish backstop as Barclay and Cox headed to Brussels for more talks. However, the negotiations failed to deliver and the mood was described as tense with robust arguments put forward by either side, but the bottom line is that EU officials were left sceptical about the prospects of reaching any new agreement by the end of the week, or even in time for the March 21-22 Summit after offering an option that did not satisfy the UK delegation. The Attorney General was reportedly asked to re-write his proposal and talks are ongoing through today, over the weekend, with PM May now scheduled to see EC President Juncker next Monday, just a day before the voting begins again in Whitehall – meaningful on March 12, then no deal and extension on consecutive days thereafter if the former is rejected again (which latest straw polling suggests). Cable plumbed new depths for the week around 1.3020 from circa 1.3275 at best, but got a late boost from unsubstantiated remarks suggesting EU’s Barnier may be willing to offer Britain a unilateral get out from the customs union.

* CAD: The Loonie has endured a torrid week due several negative factors including a ramp up in diplomatic tensions between Canada and China, a relatively pronounced retracement in oil prices and a more uncertain/cautious BoC that acknowledged last week’s disappointing Q4 growth figures and the fact that this puts the economy on a weaker footing for the first 3 months of 2019, if not longer. Usd/Cad duly rallied from sub-1.3300 to 1.3450+ before fading after Friday’s NA jobs data revealed almost 3 times as many jobs created in Canada vs the US in February, plus positive comments on the USMCA front as US President Trump claimed the deal is done and ready to be passed to Congress.

* SEK/NOK: The Scandi Crowns have not been immune to the overall deterioration in risk appetite, and faint signs that the Riksbank may not be as certain about pressing ahead with further policy normalisation in H1 this year added to the dovish Central Bank vibe, if not narrative. Meanwhile, the Nok was also a victim of crude’s demise and not helped by Norway’s SWF deciding to phase out energy investments. Eur/Sek firmly above 10.6000 vs sub-10.5000 at the lows and Eur/Nok closer to 9.8800 than 9.7370.

* COMING-UP: Monday: Eurogroup meeting. Tuesday: Brexit Meaningful Vote (TBC), ECOFIN meeting, UK GDP, US CPI. Wednesday: Eurozone Industrial Production, US PPI. Thursday: BoJ Rate Decision, US Retail Sales. Friday: Eurozone CPI (final), NY Fed Mfg, Uni of Michigan (Prelim), US JOLTS (Jan), US Industrial Production. Click here for full briefing.

EU Brexit negotiator Barnier says EU has proposed to the UK a legally binding interpretation of the Brexit Withdrawal Agreement, says EU commits to give UK the option to exit the Single Customs Territory unilaterally
content:
• Adds the other elements of the backstop must be maintained to avoid a hard border
  • The arbitration panel can already, under Article 178 WA, give UK the right to a proportionate suspension of its obligations under the backstop, as a last resort, if EU breaches its best endeavours/good faith obligations to negotiate alternative solutions, Barnier said
  • EU ready to give legal force to all commitments from January letter of EU President and EU's Juncker, through joint interpretative statement. 
  • Barnier says this will render best endeavour/good faith obligations even more actionable by an arbitration panel
  • Adds EU will continue working intensively over the coming days to ensure that the UK leaves the EU with an agreement.

content:

  • Costco (COST) Q2 2019 EPS USD 2.01 vs. exp. USD 1.67, revenue USD 35.4bln vs. exp. USD 35.65bln; comp sales +5.4%.
  • Exxon Mobil (XOM), Chevron (CVX), ConocoPhillips (COP) – Norway’s sovereign wealth fund, the world’s largest, reported it is looking to cut its stake in oil firms
  • Visa (V) – The Bank of England is implementing an independent review board of the co. after its operating system broke down in the UK for a short period in 2018.

 

8th March 2019

EARNINGS

  • Costco (COST) Q2 2019 EPS USD 2.01 vs. exp. USD 1.67, revenue USD 35.4bln vs. exp. USD 35.65bln; comp sales +5.4%. Costco announced it would be raising its minimum wage to USD 15 from USD 14. (Newswires)
  • Marvell (MRVL) Q4 adj. EPS USD 0.25 vs. exp. USD 0.25, revenue USD 745mln vs. exp. USD 740.31mln; lowers Q1 EPS and revenue guidance. (Newswires)
  • National Beverage (FIZZ) Q3 EPS USD 0.53 vs. exp. USD 0.76, revenue USD 220.9mln vs. exp. USD 236.99mln. (Newswires)

DJIA

  • DowDuPont (DWDP) – The chemicals co.’s board has approved its separation of its Materials Science Division, which will become the new Dow on April 1st. (Newswires)
  • Exxon Mobil (XOM), Chevron (CVX), ConocoPhillips (COP) – Norway’s sovereign wealth fund, the world’s largest, reported it is looking to cut its stake in oil firms - which it has in XOM, CVX, COP – in order to reduce its overexposure to oil. (Newswires)
  • Visa (V) – The Bank of England is implementing an independent review board of the co. after its operating system broke down in the UK for a short period in 2018. (Newswires)

S&P500

  • Altria (MO) – The tobacco co. has completed its USD 1.8bln 45% stake investment in the Canadian cannabis co. Cronos Group (CRON). (Newswires)
  • Lockheed Martin (LMT) – Turkey is struggling to gain US clearance in its purchase of F-35 jets, this comes after the country purchased S-400 defence systems from Russia, Turkish Defence Minister said the co. is working to resolve the issue. (Newswires)
  • Newmont Mining (NEM), Barrick Gold (GOLD) – Barrick CEO Mark Bristow said on CNBC’s Mad Money that the Newmont merger deal would create shareholder value, something the gold mining industry has lacked recently. (CNBC)
  • PepsiCo (PEP) – The beverages co. has appointed Kohl’s (KSS) CEO Michelle Gass to its board of directors, effective March 6th. (Newswires)
  • Phillip Morris (PM) – The tobacco co., alongside its Indian partner Godfrey Phillips, have been probed by Indian authorities, as reported Wednesday, but the probe appears to be much larger than originally expected. (Newswires)
  • Spotify (SPOT), Google (GOOG, GOOGL), Pandora (P) and Amazon (AMZN) – The co.s have filed an appeal against a recent copyright ruling that would increase pay-outs to songwriters by 44%. (Variety)
  • Twitter (TWTR) – The social media co. has increased the power of its reporting system as it looks to protect personal information. (Newswires)

NASDAQ

  • Amazon (AMZN) – Many of the retailer’s suppliers are panicking after the co. has halted purchases from them, where it’s pushing the vendors to begin selling their products directly on Amazon to reduce costs. subject: Fixed and FX latest: paltry US payrolls underpins debt and undermines Dollar
content: After some volatile and knee-jerk trade, bonds are settling higher and the Usd lower as the weak headline NFP number overshadows other components in the BLS report that are more upbeat. Bunds are back up around par and Gilts have pared more losses from their 127.05 low, but the DXY has slipped to a fresh session base of 97.232 ahead of the Wall Street open, and with the bulk of the Usd’s losses in the G10 space suffered against the Cad that has been given a welcome boost from back-to-back strong Canadian payroll prints.

Nomura Quants say CTAs liquidating long US equity positions
content:
US equity markets have declined significantly, losing upwardmomentum, Nomura says, and the bank believes the current correction in the US stock market is due to either:

  • Technical-based trend followers rapidly cutting their “loss-making” longpositions on major US equity futures market.
  • By contrast, some major positive factors that have supported financial market conditions on the fundamentals side, e.g. hopes of a US-China trade agreement and major central banks’ dovish shift have continued, and because some medium and long-term investors are looking for opportunities to buy-on-dips in the US equity market.

Adds that "looking at the market, we believe the former factor is dominating trends."

RANsquawk Daily US Opening News - 8th March 2019
content:
To download the report, please click hereIf you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • Chinese trade surplus shrinks, as exports sink to 3 year lows
  •  European indices [Euro Stoxx 50 -0.6%] extend losses amidst global growth concerns
  • Dxy drifts from YTD peaks awaiting US payrolls
  •  Looking ahead, highlights include US & Canadian Jobs Report, ECB's Mersch Speaking

 

ASIA

Asian equity markets were negative across board on spill-over selling from their global peers after the ECB's latest policy announcement, while sentiment further deteriorated on disappointing Chinese trade data. ASX 200 (-1.0%) and Nikkei 225 (-2.1%) were lower with the top-weighted financials sector front-running the broad-based declines in Australia, while Japanese sentiment was dragged by a stronger currency with Kawasaki Kisen the worst hit after it widened its FY net loss guidance by fivefold to JPY 100bln. Hang Seng (-1.9%) and Shanghai Comp. (-4.4%) slumped with underperformance seen in the mainland in which the CSI 300 slipped by the most so far this year of more than 3% in early trade, as concern regarding global growth took its toll and with selling exacerbated after Chinese trade data showed the steepest decline in exports for 3 years. Finally, 10yr JGBs tracked the gains in T-notes amid declining yields in the aftermath of the dovish ECB, while the widespread risk averse tone and BoJ presence in the market in the short-end also contributed to the support for government bonds.

PBoC skipped open market operations for a net weekly drain of CNY 220bln vs. last week's CNY 160bln net injection. (Newswires) PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.7235 (Prev. 6.7110)

Chinese Trade Balance (USD)(Feb) 4.1B vs. Exp. 26.4B (Prev. 39.2B); lowest since March 2018. (Newswires) Chinese Exports (USD)(Feb) Y/Y -20.7% vs. Exp. -4.8% (Prev. 9.1%); largest decline since February 2016. Chinese Imports (USD)(Feb) Y/Y -5.2% vs. Exp. -1.4% (Prev. -1.5%)

China Senior Diplomat Wang Yi said China will protect rights of its people and companies, while he added that justice will have its day regarding Huawei and that US-China disputes at this stage do not represent a long-term trend in bilateral relations. Furthermore, Wang commented that it is normal for there to be competition between the 2 nations and hopes US drops zero-sum thinking and meets China halfway. (Newswires)

Japanese GDP (Q4 F) Q/Q 0.5% vs. Exp. 0.4% (Prev. 0.3%). (Newswires) Japanese GDP (Q4 F) Y/Y 1.9% vs. Exp. 1.8% (Prev. 1.4%) 

US

US & China have not set a date for a US President Trump and Chinese Premier Xi summit, no preperation for the summit is underway as both sides to resolve the majority of issues before the leaders meet; WSJ China Correspondent. (WSJ)

GEOPOLITICAL

US official stated that they need to see meaningful and verifiable action regarding denuclearization from North Korea soon but added that the magnitude 2.1 tremor in North Korea is not causing alarm. (Newswires/Yonhap/Korea Times)

UK/EU

UK PM May will urge the EU to help get her Brexit deal through House of Commons by agreeing to legally binding changes to the backstop. (BBC)

UK PM May is reportedly being warned by Cabinet 'remainers' that she will lose control of Brexit next week unless she holds a series of humiliating votes regarding alternatives to her deal if it fails to get parliament approval for a 2nd time. (The Times)

UK opposition Labour Party will not support a new referendum on Brexit in all circumstances, according to reports which added the party will only support final say vote on PM May's deal and could back a softer Brexit without giving public a say. (Independent)

There will not be a meeting today between Brexit Secretary Barclay, Attorney General Cox and EU's Chief Negotiator Barnier; BBC's Fleming. (BBC)

There will be a three-line whip for Tory MP's on the Brexit votes next Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday; Buzzfeed's Wickham. (Twitter) For reference, a 'three-line whip' is a strict instruction to attend and vote, a breach of which would typically result in serious consequences.

EU ambassadors have been summoned to a meeting about Brexit this afternoon at 14:00 GMT; BBC's Fleming. (Twitter)

EU Commission says the EU has offered ideas on reassurances for Britain regarding the backstop, have nothing to add. (Newswires)

UK PM May has no plans to travel to Brussels over the weekend, talks will continue over the weekend; PM Spokesperson. (Newswires)

CENTRAL BANKS

BoE's Tenreyro sees slight softening in core inflation measures and doesn't see a rush to hike rates. (Herald Scotland)

ECB's Villeroy says expects French economy to grow by more than Germany in 2019, and above average in the Euro Zone. (Newswires)

ECB's Nowotny says the decision to launch TLTRO in September is due to the need for careful preparation; details to be announced in at latest June. (Newswires)

ECB's Vasiliauskas says the ECB acting preemptively a reaction was needed, adding that the ECB has the time until September to agree on the TLTRO details. (Newswires)

Riksbank's Floden says he is surprised by the recent crown weakening, adding that the the weaker crown will have a short term effect on inflation, and will need to be weighed into policy. (Newswires)

EQUITIES

Major European indicies are in negative territory [Euro Stoxx 50 -0.6%] as global growth concerns continue to dominate market sentiment; following yesterday’s ECB TLTRO announcement, pushing back of rate guidance and lowering of growth & inflation forecasts. Overnight the Shanghai Composite (-4.4%) was at its worst level in 5 months; also exacerbated by poor Chinese trade data. Sectors are broadly in the red, with the automobile sector lagging on the aforementioned Chinese trade data and growth concerns. Significantly underperforming its peers at the bottom of the Stoxx 600 are GVC Holdings (-17.0%) after the Co’s CEO sold 2.1mln worth of shares alongside the Chairman selling 900k shares; with both sales at the price of GBP 6.66/shr. Elsewhere, and towards the top of the Stoxx 600 are Azimut (+2.1%) benefiting from being upgraded at Kepler Cheuvreux. Elsewhere, following the Norwegian government stating the sovereign wealth fund should cut energy stocks from the investment benchmark, there was an immediate negative reaction in energy names including Total (+0.6%), BP (-1.5%) and Shell (-1.9%).

FX

JPY - The traditional and enduring safe haven currency is outperforming amidst heightened risk off sentiment, as worrying Chinese trade data and an unexpected decline in German manufacturing orders exacerbate global growth concerns. Usd/Jpy has subsequently retreated further from 112.00+ highs to just under 111.00, and through key technical support in the shape of the 200 DMA at 111.39.

DXY - The index and Greenback overall have succumbed to a bout of broad profit-taking and consolidation along with the aforementioned stronger demand for the Yen, as attention turns towards the looming NFP report and at least partly away from Thursday’s dovish ECB policy moves. The DXY has duly backed off from a new 2019 peak at 97.711 to straddle the 97.500 level as G10 (and EM) counterparts claw back some lost ground.

NZD/AUD - Although risk aversion has been stoked by the factors noted above, short-covering and cross-positioning have protected the Antipodean Dollars from further depreciation and fall-out. In fact, the Kiwi has rebounded firmly enough from recent lows to vie with the Jpy at the top of the major league as its Aussie peer remains depressed following recent worrying data that has prompted yet another bank to predict 2 RBA rate cuts this year. Nzd/Usd is back up over 0.6775 and Aud/Nzd slips below 1.0350, as Aud/Usd languishes between 0.7028-04 with a hefty 1.5 bn option expiry at the 0.7000 strike exerting another gravitational pull.

EUR/CHF - Some respite for the single currency and Franc, with Eur/Usd pivoting 1.1200 after testing a key chart support at 1.1187 on follow-through selling in wake of the ECB’s decision to offer more TLTROs and delay rate hikes. However, the headline pair looks hemmed in by option expiries at 1.1220-25 (1.6 bn) and 1.1250 (2.6 bn), and with nothing significant on the downside in terms of technical levels until 1.1110-33, aside from another expiry at 1.1150 (1 bn). Meanwhile, Usd/Chf is in a tight band around 1.0100 and now eyeing NFP for the next directional lead.

GBP/CAD - Marginal underperformers, with Cable looking increasingly bearish after losing grip of 1.3100 and hopes of a Brexit breakthrough appearing more and more forlorn as the latest EU offer on the backstop is not deemed sufficient to appease the majority of UK MPs that rejected the WA at the 1st time of asking. The Loonie has stabilised somewhat after its midweek collapse on a more cautious and uncertain BoC, but remains on the backfoot vs its US rival around 1.3450 ahead of jobs data from both sides of the NA divide.

SEK/NOK - The Scandi crowns are both weaker vs the Eur and Usd, with the former ruffled by comments from Riskbank’s Floden expressing surprise at the Sek’s recent decline and the fact that the ECB’s policy actions in March will be taken into account when the Swedish Central Bank meet at the end of next month. A rebound in household spending and upward revisions to back data has nudged Eur/Sek off the highs, but the pair remains above 10.6000, while a deeper retreat in oil prices is undermining the Nok, as Norway’s SWF pulls the plug on energy stocks in its benchmark portfolio. Eur/Nok currently around 9.8500.

FIXED INCOME

Although off best levels, the core Eurozone bond has regrouped again after another bout of consolidation that briefly dragged prices below parity. However, Gilts continue to underperform and just slipped to a new, albeit very marginal Liffe low of 127.14 and EZ peripheral paper has unwound quite a bit of dovish ECB premium and outperformance vs Bunds/OATs as spreads edge back in. Meanwhile, US Treasuries are rooted near the base of their overnight ranges with the curve incrementally steeper as NFP looms.

COMMODITIES

Brent (-1.7%) and WTI (-1.6%) prices are continuing to extend upon their losses, as global growth concerns weigh on risk tone; both WTI and Brent are trading at the bottom of the sessions range, with WTI prices dropping under USD 56.00/bbl to the downside exacerbating the price decline; with session lows of around USD 55.80/bbl. Looking ahead we have the Baker Hughes Rig count, a decline in the crude rig count would be the third consecutive week of oil rigs decline; and as such may provide some reprieve to Brent and WTI prices. 

Gold (+0.6%) is shining as the yellow metal benefits from the global growth concerns which are dominating markets. With gold at the top of it’s USD 10/oz range, trading around USD 1294.60/oz. Conversely, copper prices are down afflicted by the poor Chinese trade data exacerbating growth concerns in the worlds largest importer of the metals.

The Loonie has stabilised somewhat after its midweek collapse on a more cautious and uncertain BoC, but remains on the backfoot vs its US rival around 1.3450 ahead of jobs data from both sides of the NA divide.

SEK/NOK 

The Scandi crowns are both weaker vs the Eur and Usd, with the former ruffled by comments from Riskbank’s Floden expressing surprise at the Sek’s recent decline and the fact that the ECB’s policy actions in March will be taken into account when the Swedish Central Bank meet at the end of next month. A rebound in household spending and upward revisions to back data has nudged Eur/Sek off the highs, but the pair remains above 10.6000, while a deeper retreat in oil prices is undermining the Nok, as Norway’s SWF pulls the plug on energy stocks in its benchmark portfolio. Eur/Nok currently around 9.8500.

content: Ignoring, or simply contradicting bullish external impulses at the time, UK debt and STIR contracts started the final session of the week on the back foot having piggy-backed ECB inspired gains on Thursday. The 10 year debt future is consolidating within a 127.18-34 range compared to its 127.46 previous settlement, while the 3 month strip is flat to 1.5 ticks adrift vs -2 ticks at worst earlier. Looking ahead, Friday’s domestic agenda is barren and Brexit looks set to take a back seat for once given no scheduled meetings with EU officials, although talks are bound to be ongoing ahead of PM May and EC President Juncker next get together on Monday (on the eve of UK’s Parliament’s 2nd meaningful vote). More immediately, the monthly US jobs data will likely form the pre-weekend highlight, as usual.

subject: RANsquawk Daily European Opening News - 8th March 2019
content:
To download the report, please click hereIf you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • Asian equity markets were negative across board on spill-over selling from their global peers after the ECB's latest policy announcement and disappointing Chinese trade data
  • UK PM May will urge the EU to help get her Brexit deal through House of Commons by agreeing to legally binding changes to the backstop
  • Sources reported that the ECB is said to doubt 2019 outlook was cut by enough and that President Draghi is said to have pushed for ECB stimulus package
  • Looking ahead, highlights include German Industrial Orders, US & Canadian Jobs Report, ECB's Nowotny & Mersch Speaking

8th March 2019

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets were negative across board on spill-over selling from their global peers after the ECB's latest policy announcement, while sentiment further deteriorated on disappointing Chinese trade data. ASX 200 (-1.0%) and Nikkei 225 (-2.1%) were lower with the top-weighted financials sector front-running the broad-based declines in Australia, while Japanese sentiment was dragged by a stronger currency with Kawasaki Kisen the worst hit after it widened its FY net loss guidance by fivefold to JPY 100bln. Hang Seng (-1.6%) and Shanghai Comp. (-3.5%) slumped with underperformance seen in the mainland in which the CSI 300 slipped by the most so far this year of more than 3% in early trade, as concern regarding global growth took its toll and with selling exacerbated after Chinese trade data showed the steepest decline in exports for 3 years. Finally, 10yr JGBs tracked the gains in T-notes amid declining yields in the aftermath of the dovish ECB, while the widespread risk averse tone and BoJ presence in the market in the short-end also contributed to the support for government bonds.

PBoC skipped open market operations for a net weekly drain of CNY 220bln vs. last week's CNY 160bln net injection. (Newswires) PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.7235 (Prev. 6.7110)

Chinese Trade Balance (USD)(Feb) 4.1B vs. Exp. 26.4B (Prev. 39.2B); lowest since March 2018. (Newswires) Chinese Exports (USD)(Feb) Y/Y -20.7% vs. Exp. -4.8% (Prev. 9.1%); largest decline since February 2016. Chinese Imports (USD)(Feb) Y/Y -5.2% vs. Exp. -1.4% (Prev. -1.5%)

China Senior Diplomat Wang Yi said China will protect rights of its people and companies, while he added that justice will have its day regarding Huawei and that US-China disputes at this stage do not represent a long-term trend in bilateral relations. Furthermore, Wang commented that it is normal for there to be competition between the 2 nations and hopes US drops zero-sum thinking and meets China halfway. (Newswires)

Chinese officials are said to be wary of reaching a quick trade deal with officials said not to share US President Trump’s optimism, while they are also reportedly wary final terms might be less favourable given Trump’s propensity for last minute changes. (NYT)

Japanese GDP (Q4 F) Q/Q 0.5% vs. Exp. 0.4% (Prev. 0.3%). (Newswires) Japanese GDP (Q4 F) Y/Y 1.9% vs. Exp. 1.8% (Prev. 1.4%) 

UK/EU

UK PM May will urge the EU to help get her Brexit deal through House of Commons by agreeing to legally binding changes to the backstop. (BBC)

UK PM May is reportedly being warned by Cabinet 'remainers' that she will lose control of Brexit next week unless she holds a series of humiliating votes regarding alternatives to her deal if it fails to get parliament approval for a 2nd time. (The Times)

UK opposition Labour Party will not support a new referendum on Brexit in all circumstances, according to reports which added the party will only support final say vote on PM May's deal and could back a softer Brexit without giving public a say. (Independent)

EU's Brexit offer was said to fall short of UK demands and the EU is said to make a new offer to the UK on Brexit backstop. (Newswires)

BoE's Tenreyro sees slight softening in core inflation measures and doesn't see a rush to hike rates. (Herald Scotland)

ECB sources stated the ECB opted for more radical easing measures only after growth projections appeared to be a bigger than feared slowdown, while it was also noted that hawks gave little resistance and conceded that delaying decisions until April was non-sensical. In related news, sources reported that the ECB is said to doubt 2019 outlook was cut by enough and that President Draghi is said to have pushed for ECB stimulus package, while the ECB is not going to be rushing for TLTRO details as soon as April and is mulling TLTRO rate at a premium over benchmark. (Newswires) 

FX

In FX markets, the DXY remained firmly above the 97.00 level and was the main benefactor following the ECB’s dovish triple whammy. This saw EUR/USD decline by more than 2 points to below 1.1200 and GBP/USD relinquished the 1.3100 handle to the downside amid Brexit-related pessimism with only limited progress reportedly made in discussions with the EU, which seemingly provided Morgan Stanley a more favourable entrance as it took a long GBP/USD position at the NY close with a target at 1.3650 and a stop at 1.2850. Elsewhere, USD/JPY and JPY-crosses were pressured by the risk-averse tone and due to flows into the JPY following better than expected GDP and Current Account figures from Japan, while antipodeans’ attempts to nurse losses were negated by the poor Chinese trade data with AUD/USD also hampered by a large option expiry of 1.5bln at the 0.7000 level for today’s New York cut and as NAB joined the growing list of banks calling for 2 rate cuts from the RBA this year.

BoC Deputy Governor Patterson said need more data to know if the weakness in Q4 2018 is temporary or will be more persistent and that bank staff are looking to see if the neutral rate range needs to change, while Patterson added that the economic 'detour' predicted at the end of 2018 may be longer than expected. (Newswires)

COMMODITIES

Commodities were subdued with demand hampered by the widespread risk-averse tone in which WTI crude futures further retreated from resistance near the USD 57.00/bbl level, with the recent pressure attributed to the global growth fears. Elsewhere, gold prices were flat as the USD held firm post-dovish ECB and with participants tentative heading into the latest NFP jobs data, while copper marginally extended on losses after underperformance in its largest buyer China in the wake of abysmal trade data.

China February YTD crude oil imports rose 12.5% Y/Y, while iron ore imports declined 5.5% Y/Y and copper products imports fell 0.6% Y/Y. (Newswires)

Various Chinese ports have implemented stricter clearance procedures for Australian cargoes which is further pressuring demand for Australian thermal coal, according to reports citing market sources. (Hellenic Shipping News) 

GEOPOLITICS

North Korean long-range missile site appears operational according to recent satellite images, while there were also reports of a magnitude 2.1 tremor in North Korea. In related news, US President Trump said he is disappointed by reported rebuilding of North Korea’s missile site, while a US official separately commented that they need to see meaningful and verifiable action regarding denuclearization from North Korea soon but added that the magnitude 2.1 tremor in North Korea is not causing alarm. (Newswires/Yonhap/Korea Times)

US

The Treasury complex took its cue from European govvies, after the ECB over-delivered, pushing back its timeline to lift rates and announcing another round of liquidity measures. Yields were lower by between 4bps and 6bps, at settlement, led by the belly. A bout of profit-taking after the European close did little to halt the march higher, which was further aided by the slide in US stocks. The stock slide seemed to stabilise around half an hour before the cash close, which lent some negative ticks to the T-Note. Friday's payrolls is now the next major catalyst for the complex. US T-note futures (M9) settled 16 ticks higher at 122-21.

Fed's Brainard (voter, dove) said increases in risk warrant downward revision of the rate path even if economic outlook stays the same, while she added that it is clear the potential US economic growth rate is lower than before and that she does not want to prejudge what sort of rate moves would be appropriate late in the year. Furthermore, Brainard commented that policymakers are carefully monitoring leveraged loans and bonds vulnerable to downgrade, as well as funds that hold these assets. (Newswires)

ASIA-PAC MID-SESSION UPDATE: Asia stocks slump on global growth concerns
content:
Asia equity markets are negative across board on spillover selling from their global peers after the ECB's TLTRO announcement and forecast downgrades added to the ongoing global growth concerns, while participants are also cautious ahead of key-risk China trade data and US NFP releases. ASX 200 (-0.8%) and Nikkei 225 (-1.5%) are lower with the top-weighted financials sector front-running the broad-based declines in Australia, while Japanese sentiment is dragged by a stronger currency with Kawasaki Kisen the worst hit after it widened its FY net loss guidance by fivefold to JPY 100bln. Hang Seng (-1.1%) and Shanghai Comp. (-1.2%) have also slumped with early underperformance seen in the mainland in which the CSI 300 slipped by the most so far this year of more than 3%, as concern regarding global growth took its toll and amid cautiousness ahead of the looming Chinese trade data.

In FX markets, the DXY remains firmly above the 97.00 level and was the main benefactor following the ECB’s dovish triple whammy, in which it announced a fresh round of TLTROs, cut growth forecasts and indicated that rates would be kept on hold through 2019 vs. Prev. guidance for rates to be kept on hold through summer. This saw EUR/USD decline over 2 points to below 1.1200 and GBP/USD relinquished the 1.3100 handle to the downside amid Brexit-related pessimism as only limited progress was said to have been made in discussions with the EU, which seemingly provided Morgan Stanley a more favourable entrance as it took a long GBP/USD position at the NY close with a target at 1.3650 and a stop at 1.2850. Elsewhere, USD/JPY and JPY-crosses are kept subdued by the risk-averse tone and due to flows into the JPY following better than expected GDP and Current Account figures from Japan, while antipodeans’ attempts to nurse losses are kept limited ahead of the key Chinese data and with a large option expiry in AUD/USD of 1.5bln at the 0.7000 level for Friday’s New York cut.

Finally, 10yr JGBs are higher as they track the gains in T-notes and amid declining yields in the aftermath of the dovish ECB, while the widespread risk averse tone and BoJ presence in the market in the short-end also contribute to support for government bonds.
